title: Friday, 6th September 2019
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas Good morning all
11:11 am
BE11:11am

Good morning, welcome, how the devil are you? Seems it's time for another Markets Live, FTAlphaville's thing with etc.

VV75 morning

Gross Loydman Morning!
marktime Mhoroi

Pete morning

A former colleague of Mr Hall said: “He’s got sharp elbows and a lot of ideas. But the environment of tracing assets for a listed company where you’re driven by the bottom line encourages risk-taking that could blow up in your face.”

He added: “It didn’t surprise me when I heard about the sex tape. You use what information is at your disposal in this line of work and Dan as much as anyone would.”

cheeckychappy What happened to @Nightingale
cheeckychappy ?

Maverick Morning all
11:20 am
BE11:20am

And speaking generally, surely Burford's keenness to get on the right side of its client liabilities is exactly the point. That's the USP, and it's not really a big surprise that litigation can be a bit ugly.

BornCynic Have I mixed up the bookmarks again?
VV75 it's a taste of American grandstanding in court, smearing the opposition credibility.

AnyWAY.

undefined
PaddingtonResearch What this story adds to the short case is that they are being sued for 91m - yet that does not look like it is being recorded as a liability. And this is not an isolated incedent - look at the divorce case - andother 200m lawsuit... plenty more too
tangledodyssey Yes, Hollywood movie script stuff.
Soundbuy Liberum keen on ITV again
tangledodyssey There are several known cases where they are on the receiving end of litigation, seemingly not disclosed fully in their reports.
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Okay, where are we?

BE11:24am

Soundbuy mentions Liberum pushing ITV.

tangledodyssey ITV has run up 15% in a couple of weeks.
BE11:24am

That'd give me some deadtime to get my stuff together, so here's that.

11:24 am
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 120.95, down 0.25 (-0.21%), High: 122.85, Low: 120.80, Volume: 2.44m
VV75 relentless mentioning of it being a target
BE11:25am

We raise our Target Price to 180p from 145p, as we switch back to valuing ITV on a DCF basis and not a adjusted PE multiple, as we feel more comfortable about the pictures. There have been no change to our forecasts and we feel (famous last words) for 2019 at least, there may be an end to the advertising downgrades. If the Government does end up spending £100m on advertising for a No Deal Brexit, ITV is likely to benefit significantly in Q4 with £25m equating to a 3-4% boost to Q4 Total Advertising. Our view is also that, politically, an endgame on Brexit seems to be approaching and that the elimination of uncertainty itself may help ITV as advertisers are better able to plan ahead. At just over 8x adjusted FY19E PE and a near 7% dividend yield with a more than sustaionable balance sheet, reiterate the Buy.

tangledodyssey Liberum have been enthusiastic on ITV for years and years now.
BE11:25am

Is there a bid angle? Of course there is.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

M&A in the background. There are noticeable signs that overseas players are taking advantage of both the weak pound and uncertainty in specific UK media names to make targeted M&A approaches e.g. Hasbro’s recent agreed takeover for content firm Entertainment One and Takeaway.com’s bid for Just Eat. We think this is likely to continue and ITV, with both its market leadership position and strong content arm, should be a target, especially as there are clear signs (in the US) of the Broadcasters starting to make progress in their digital offerings and push more effectively the Total Advertising proposition.

tangledodyssey Govt spend on no-deal advertising was the push factor recently
marktime Boycott praising Smith excellence for the most ugly uncoachable unorthodox strokes, whatever next, bring on the bouncer

Soundbuy Is Liberty stake a deterrent?

undefined

Next up, SIG.

SIG PLC (SHI:LSE): Last: 122.40, down 6.7 (-5.19%), High: 126.00, Low: 120.00, Volume: 3.09m
BE11:32am

Having been chased up last month by punter interest, reality strikes. Outlook weakish.

tangledodyssey It would also make sense to theme their channels, have an ITV Sports, an ITV Reality, etc
tangledodyssey The present multi-offering 1,2,3,4 makes no sense anymore
11:33 am
BE11:33am

And a mention that the strategic review of the Air Handling business is “well advanced”

marktime SIG putting a roof on it
BE11:34am

Which I think means a sale to Platinum Equity for £200m-ish reasonably soon.

BE11:34am

Here's Goodbody.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

SIG has reported H119 underlying PBT of £30m (pre-IFRS 16) representing yoy growth of
+20% and in line with our forecasts. There were some variances in the mix with divisional
profits slightly lower than our expectations (mainly gross margin) but offset by much better
central costs highlighting the continued focus on rebasing / controlling overheads. Cash
generation has come in stronger than anticipated with a pre-IFRS 16 net debt of £158m
(£176m H118) which compares to our forecast of £178m driven predominantly by another
strong working capital performance.

BE11:35am

While the ongoing transformation of the group is
expected to lead to further upside in H2, we believe the outlook is incrementally more
cautious with management citing “further weakening of the macro-economic backdrop,
notably in the UK and in Germany”.

BE11:35am

At first glance we will be therefore cutting our underlying PBT forecasts by £4-5m
(5-6%) to £78-79m. While the latter could be viewed as a disappointment, it still
implies FY19 margins of just over 3% which we feel is not demanding versus an
EV/Sales multiple 0.3-0.4x. Particularly when further margin improvements are
expected and there is the prospect of a cash return with any disposal of Air
Handling.

nightingale20201 @ tangle...I seem to recall ITV Studio's key driver has been ROW...US has been one off, difficult to see how ITV could compete with NFLX, and other US media giants ..so the break-up argument has to be along the line of very niche content
11:36 am
BE11:36am

And Stifel.

BE11:37am

Headline PBT (pre-IFRS16) of £30m is up strongly and broadly in line with our expectations. There was strong profit growth in Mainland Europe despite a c.£3m impact from the French ransomware attack, and further evidence of transformation in the UK&I in a challenging end-market. Leverage continues to improve, reducing to 1.4x. The strategic review of Air Handling is "well advanced", and our base case remains for a sale of £200m+ to be announced in the coming months. The outlook highlights significant caution in the market heading into the group's key trading months, and we anticipate cutting out adj. PBT estimate by c.5% on a pre-IFRS 16 basis. Whilst there is evidence the strategy is delivering, end-markets are providing little support - Hold.

undefined
marktime Most surprising is Greene King report of lower sales across a scorching Summer. What are they blaming that on
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Speaking of disposals, Kleinmanwire saying Brinks has made an approach to buy G4S Cash Solutions.

G4S PLC (GFS:LSE): Last: 190.55, up 15.35 (+8.76%), High: 191.60, Low: 175.00, Volume: 3.08m
marktime All about asset disposal selling off £50M property a year
sprout marktime - comps. Last summer was world cup.
BE11:40am

Which we knew was for sale, right? Offically speaking a demerger in the pipeline but management effectively raised the for sale sign, to use the journalistic cliche.

marktime We had a world cup this summer with Greene King as a lead sposnor advertiser
11:41 am
BE11:41am

PE and peers both nearly guaranteed to be interested, which makes the response to the story somewhat surprising. Barclays with the valuation work.

BE11:41am

Our analysis suggests the Cash Solutions business could be worth between £1.5bn and £2.0bn. Conservatively putting £1.7bn into our sum-of-the-parts implies a value of 220p.

BE11:42am

And RBC from a little while back.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

The recent weakness, which we believe reflects some forced selling and EM concerns, has left the group trading on a c.15% discount to its SOP valuation. In other words, we believe the market is factoring in a demerger of Cash Solutions and some associated incremental costs and dis-synergies. We don't think a demerger will create value and it doesn't solve the debt problem. However, the company is running a dual track process and we do see the potential for a sale of all or parts of the business over the next few months. We run numbers on a disposal and believe the resulting business is trading at a 20% discount to Securitas and 35% to the sector average. Hence, we believe investors are getting optionality on a disposal at the current price.

marktime The official beer of England cricket while we were stealing the trophy of the kiwis
BE11:43am

Our belief is that a sale would be the most preferable option for the business as it would solve 3 main issues: 1. Focus – A sale would focus the business on Security Services and Technology and free up management time to manage that business more effectively. 2. Debt – A sale would clearly bring in cash that would allow debt levels to be reduced and/or a reduction of the pension deficit. 3. Dividend rebase – Given the exceptional costs, onerous contracts and pension deficit reduction payments, the bulk of available FCF has been used to pay the dividend. A rebasing of the dividend would allow for dividend growth and more cashflow for investment/M&A etc.

Soundbuy Greene King..............a tad academic now I guess
BE11:43am

That said there are some potential issues with a sale of the business:  GFS has 40 different geographies and so it is not an easy business to manage.  There would be competitive issues (eg Loomis in the UK).  There would be limited synergies for some other players given limited overlap (eg Prosegur Cash).  Some businesses are in very difficult markets (eg South Africa).  The pension deficit especially in the UK (old Securicor) business may be a stumbling block.  There are some structural pressures in the traditional market, although there are opportunities from further outsourcing and greater use of technology.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

A reminder also that any sale proceeds would likely fall into G4S's pension deficit and £2.6bn-ish of net debt

Markkus Indeed, as evidenced by the 0.03% price reaction!

BE11:49am

I mean, good luck if the real idea here is to turn the pubs into houses: https://en.wikiped...on_Tavern,_Kilburn

BE11:50am

Greene King Q1's completely academic but here are the details anyway, via Caz.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

AGM trading statement. GNK has reported -1.8% Pub Company LFL
sales growth for the 18 weeks to 1 September (vs. JPMe +0.5% LFL for
FY20E), implying a two year average growth rate of 0.5%. The Q419 (16
weeks to the 28th April) LFL was +2.4%, representing two-year average
growth of-0.2%, so we regard this as a mild q/q underlying acceleration.
Moreover, the last seven weeks’ performance indicates good momentum
exiting the summer. Given the recommended offer by CKA, we expect a
neutral share price response.
 Pub Company LFL in Q1 20 of -1.8% was influenced by the mixed
summer (colder, wetter at the beginning of summer May-July, giving
way to better weather in late summer). The Coffer Peach Business
tracker for managed pubs has averaged -1% over May-July, with GNK
underperforming the tracker when compared against this period on y/y
basis. We note, however, that the tracker data excludes the better weather
of August (and easier August comp) whereas GNK’s result does not.
GNK's growth accelerated to +1.5% in the past seven weeks (likely
accelerating on an underlying basis as well). On a two-year average
basis, our calculation of GNK’s result is 0.5%, vs the Peach Tracker at
+1.0%.
 Pub Partners heavily impacted by tough comp as anticipated. Q1 20
LFL net income was -4.2%, impacted by the tough summer comparatives
for beer sales. LFL profit was not disclosed.
 Brewing appears weaker than trend. For the first 18 weeks total
brewed volumes were -6.5% with own-brewed volumes –7.9%. A
comparison to the UK ale market was not provided.
 Cost mitigation is “on track”. Greene King is on-track to limit net cost
inflation to £10-20m for FY20 (gross cost inflation of £45-50m and
mitigation of £30-35m), vs the £14m achieved in FY19.

BE11:51am

Read across: GNK is the latest to report for the summer, so the
incremental insight is limited. The cost environment seems stable, the ale
market seems tough and GNK’s large, diverse estate is tracking slightly
below the sector in LFL terms.

BE11:51am

And Barclays.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Greene King have released a weak trading update, although given the 850p bid from CK Noble this is probably irrelevant. LFL sales in Pub Company (Retail) have declined by 1.8% after 18 weeks. Weakness in Q1 was predictable given the tough comps from last year’s heatwave and World Cup, and indeed our FY20 LFL forecast of +0.8% was constructed assuming -1% for Q1 and +2% for the remainder of the year. However, Q1 was worse than we expected and the 1.5% post World Cup is also tracking below what we project for the rest of the year. 2 year LFLs are +1.0% after 18 weeks. Pub Partners (tenanted) LFLs are -4.2% after 16 weeks, with tough comps cited. This slightly weaker trading performance than we expect for FY20 as a whole will only actually matter if, for any reason, the recommended 850p offer bid from CK Noble is withdrawn. Elsewhere, the company is on track to meet its £10-20m net cost inflation range. Good progress is being made from a financing perspective, with the final £93m Spirit A4 bonds prepaid. Even if we generously focus on the post-World Cup comps period (+1.5% LFLs when arguably weather has been favourable), the trading update does illustrate the dilemma for investors: sector LFLs are positive (just), but cost headwinds remain, and Net Debt is generally high, so the overall investment narrative from an earnings perspective is not at first glance attractive. The flip side is that companies are in many cases asset backed, cash generative, and offer distribution possibilities – factors not lost on private/real estate/or trade buyers. We are OW Wetherspoon (best retailer in the sub-sector, long term focused), and UW Marston’s (poor cash generation track record, albeit improving) and UW Mitchells and Butlers (overall net cash flow weak, albeit trading impressively vs most sector peers). Recent M&A activity reduces our conviction in the UWs, given bid risk, but recent re-ratings also leave many sector share prices looking elevated if M&A read across euphoria dies down. Greene King valuation: FY20 PE 13.5x, EV/EBITDA 10.1x, dividend yield 3.9%

Mitchells & Butlers PLC (MAB:LSE): Last: 358.50, up 1.5 (+0.42%), High: 361.50, Low: 356.50, Volume: 30.26k

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Davy:

wayneJ I think we need a paint drying gif as a potential portrait of the day for slow news days?
BE12:05pm

The management of Smurfit Kappa Group (SKG) and DS Smith presented at our annual Industrial Conference in New York this week. From a sector perspective, there were two significant take-outs. The first is that the demand environment in Europe remains solid (c.2% growth in line with our forecast) despite the deterioration in underlying economic indicators. This suggests that structural demand drivers are real. In this environment, containerboard prices are likely to remain stable.

BE12:06pm

The second and more important takeout is the improved discipline around corrugated pricing. It is likely that box prices will fall by less than the 4% we have assumed for the second half of this year. DS Smith, historically more aggressive on pricing, now appears more focused on margins than volumes. Both companies this week issued bonds with record low (e
less than or equal to 1.5%) coupons and both generate returns on capital and free cash flow yields of over 10%. The potential to create economic value is therefore substantial. Equity market valuations look wrong in this context. With current earnings forecasts now looking very achievable, the potential for a re-rating is significant.

Soundbuy Cheers for that...........et bon w/end all
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

I wish I got invites to kraftliner conferences.
